page.title: 07WITHIEL FLOREY CHURCH
page.content: St. Mary Magdalene, Withiel Florey. The great days of this tiny parish were during the excavation of iron ore on the Brendon Hills in the nineteenth century. Evidence of these workings can still be seen in the north of the parish reminding one of the links with Wales and the threat to turn these hills into another Rhondda. In was during these years around 1871 that the church became what you see today. The tower is partly 13th century and in the fifteenth century there were other alterations. On the feast of Epiphany 1871 an almost new church was dedicated, the chancel had been rebuilt and the nave improved. The mistrels gallery was also removed and the stained glass renewed. Tiles also replaced the old pavement. However the Noerman font still remains.
